trans-unit.source: Paints an area with a linear gradient.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> paints an area with a linear gradient.
A linear gradient defines a gradient along a line.

The line's end points are defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> properties of the linear gradient.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> brush paints its <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.GradientStops%2A> along this line.
The default linear gradient is diagonal.

In the default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being painted, and its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being painted.
The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path.
The following illustration shows a diagonal gradient.
A line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point.
![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient")
A diagonal linear gradient
The next illustration shows the same linear gradient, but with highlighted gradient stops.
![Gradient stops in a linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-4gradientstops.png "Gradient stops in a linear gradient")
A diagonal linear gradient with highlighted gradient stops
It is possible to specify a gradient axis that does not completely fill area being painted.
When this occurs, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.SpreadMethod%2A> property determines how the remaining area is painted.
Freezable Features
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> is a type of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object and therefore can be frozen to improve performance.
For information about <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> features, such as freezing and cloning, see [Freezable Objects Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/freezable-objects-overview.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> class.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of the brush is initialized to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> class that has the specified gradient stops.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of the brush is initialized to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.GradientStops"></xref> to set on this brush.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> class that has the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GradientStopCollection"></xref> and angle.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of the brush is initialized to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.GradientStops"></xref> to set on this brush.
A <xref href="System.Double"></xref> that represents the angle, in degrees, of the gradient.
A value of 0.0 creates a horizontal gradient, and a value of 90.0 creates a vertical gradient.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> class that has the specified start <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref>, end <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref>, and angle.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of the brush is initialized to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref> at offset 0.0.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref> at offset 1.0.
A <xref href="System.Double"></xref> that represents the angle, in degrees, of the gradient.
A value of 0.0 creates a horizontal gradient, and a value of 90.0 creates a vertical gradient.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> class that has the specified gradient stops, <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint"></xref>, and <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of the brush is initialized to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.GradientStops"></xref> to set on this brush.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint"></xref> of the gradient.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint"></xref> of the gradient.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> class that has the specified start <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref>, end <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref>, <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint"></xref>, and <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of the brush is initialized to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref> at offset 0.0.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Color"></xref> at offset 1.0.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint"></xref> of the gradient.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint"></xref> of the gradient.
Creates a modifiable clone of this <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref>, making deep copies of this object's values.
When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.
This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object).
For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
A modifiable clone of the current object.
The cloned object's <xref href="System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen"></xref> property will be `false` even if the source's <xref href="System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen"></xref> property was `true.`
Creates a modifiable clone of this <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush"></xref> object, making deep copies of this object's current values.
Resource references, data bindings, and animations are not copied, but their current values are.
This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object).
For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.CloneCurrentValue%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
A modifiable clone of the current object.
The cloned object's <xref href="System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen"></xref> property will be `false` even if the source's <xref href="System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen"></xref> property was `true`.
Gets or sets the ending two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> paints a gradient along a line.

The line's start and end points are defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush>.
The default linear gradient is diagonal.

In the default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being filled, and its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being filled.
The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path.
The following image shows a diagonal gradient.
The black line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point.
![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient")
A diagonal linear gradient
Specifying Relative or Absolute Values

Note that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> property of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> determines whether its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> is interpreted as a relative or absolute value.

A <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox> specifies that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> value is relative to the size of the painted area.

A <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.Absolute> specifies that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> value is expressed in device independent pixels.

By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> is set to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>, making the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> a relative value.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
The ending two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient.
The default is (1,1).
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint"></xref> dependency property.
Gets or sets the starting two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> paints a gradient along a line.

The line's start and end points are defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush>.
The default linear gradient is diagonal.

In the default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being filled, and its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being filled.
The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path.
The following image shows a diagonal gradient.
The black line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point.
![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient")
A diagonal linear gradient
Specifying Relative or Absolute Values

Note that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> property of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> determines whether its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> is interpreted as a relative or absolute value.

A <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox> specifies that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> value is relative to the size of the painted area.

A <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> of <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.Absolute> specifies that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> value is expressed in device independent pixels.

By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.MappingMode%2A> is set to <xref:System.Windows.Media.BrushMappingMode.RelativeToBoundingBox>, making the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> a relative value.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
The starting two-dimensional coordinates for the linear gradient.
The default is (0, 0).
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint"></xref> dependency property.
